## Results

The 2024 Botswana general election marked a historic shift in the country's political landscape, ending nearly six decades of dominance by the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) since independence in 1966 <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>, <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>. President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded defeat to Duma Boko of the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) <citation>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-opposition-party-wins-overwhelming-majority-in-botswana-election/</citation>. Voter turnout in the 2024 parliamentary elections was 81% <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured a majority in the National Assembly, winning 36 out of the 61 seats <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>. Other parties' results were as follows: the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) secured 15 seats, becoming the second-largest party in the National Assembly <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82945</citation>; the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) obtained 5 seats <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82945</citation>; and the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) won only 4 parliamentary seats <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82945</citation>. An independent candidate, Dr. Edwin Dikoloti, won one seat <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>.

The 2024 election results have initiated discussions about representation and potential electoral reforms in Botswana <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, which currently uses the First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) majority system for National Assembly and Local Government elections <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) received 31% of the popular vote but won only 4 seats, highlighting the imbalances of the FPTP system <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/botswana-elections-2024-just-but-unfair/</citation>. The Gallagher Index could be used to measure the proportionality of parliamentary seats won in the 2024 election.

## Voter registration

In Botswana, any citizen aged 18 years and above is eligible to register to vote in national and local government elections <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php?title=Botswana_-_Obtain_a_Voters_card</citation>. To register, eligible citizens must possess a valid National Identity Card (Omang) <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation> and Voter Registration Card <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/elections.html</citation>. The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) conducts voter registration, often announcing general registration periods <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>. During these periods, citizens can visit a Registration Officer with their Omang, who will then complete a registration form <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>.

For the 2024 general elections, voter registration commenced on January 5 and concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-records-a-decline-in-registered-voters/news</citation>, <citation>https://newsinvasion24.com/botswana-wraps-up-voter-registration-for-2024-elections/</citation>. By the end of the registration period, a total of 1,038,275 voters had registered, marking an increase of 112,800 from the 2019 elections <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/over-one-million-voters-for-2024-elections/</citation>. The IEC aimed for 80% voter registration, targeting 1.3 million voters <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>, <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-exceeds-historic-1-million-mark-in-voter-registration/</citation>.

A voter who wishes to transfer their registration to a different polling station must bring their current Voter's Registration Card to a Registration Officer in the constituency where the new polling station is located <citation>https://cms2.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration-transfer</citation>. Voter registration cards are valid indefinitely, except when a voter transfers registration to a new electoral area <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php/Botswana_-_Register_as_Voter</citation>.

### Background of opposition parties before the election

Botswana has been a multi-party state since independence in 1966, but the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) has been the dominant force in the country's politics, holding power since 1969 <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>. However, the opposition parties have been challenging the BDP's dominance, especially in recent years <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>. Historically, the opposition has been fragmented and weak, but has experienced an upswell in confidence since its victory in the 2022 by-elections <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>. If the opposition parties are able to overcome factionalism and slightly increase their popular support, 2024 may mark the end of a 57-year legacy of the BDP’s rule in Botswana <citation>https://blog.bti-project.org/2024/08/29/a-bumpy-road-ahead-botswana-faces-economic-and-political-struggles-ahead-of-its-2024-general-elections/</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC), a coalition formed in the lead-up to the 2019 elections and led by Duma Boko, represented the strongest challenge to the BDP <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>. In the 2019 election, the UDC more than doubled its share of seats, from 15 to 36 <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/elections/elections/</citation>. Other key opposition parties included the Botswana Congress Party (BCP), led by Mr. Dumelang Saleshando <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/elections/elections/</citation>, the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF), which was formed just before the 2019 election by former President Ian Khama <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>, and the Alliance for Progressives (AP).

Botswana operates under a First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) electoral system, which has been criticized for disadvantaging smaller parties <citation>https://freedomhouse.org/country/botswana/freedom-world/2025</citation>. This system can magnify majorities in certain constituencies but fails to represent actual voter support across the nation <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/botswana-elections-2024-just-but-unfair/</citation>.

President Masisi stated that if re-elected in 2019, his government would prioritize enacting a law prohibiting floor crossing by MPs <citation>https://net.zimeye.org/2019/08/27/tired-of-losing-mps-botswana-president-wants-floor-crossing-laws-reviewed/</citation>.
The BPF's Onalepelo Kedikilwe won the Serowe West by-election <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/73955</citation>.
Tshekedi Khama's absence from the National Assembly was a concern that could have led to his expulsion <citation>https://thevoicebw.com/speaker-closely-monitoring-tks-absence/</citation>.

Opposition MPs rejected the Floor Crossing Bill, which was first introduced in 1998 by Gladys Kokorwe when the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) was formed <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20201210/281603833048269</citation>.

Yandani Boko indicated that backstabbing within the party contributed to his decision to resign <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/boko-cries-of-back-stabbing-sabotage/news</citation>, stating it was either he quit or commit suicide <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/it-was-either-i-quit-or-commit-suicideboko/news</citation>.

Botswana's parliament is unicameral and consists of the National Assembly with 63 seats: 57 members are directly elected in single-seat constituencies, 4 are nominated by the president and indirectly elected by the National Assembly, and 2 are ex-officio members (the president and the attorney general) <citation>https://www.indexmundi.com/botswana/legislative_branch.html</citation>.

The 12th Parliament of Botswana, running from 2019 to 2024, was dissolved on September 5, 2024, by the President <citation>https://parliament.gov.bw/documents/PARLY-SPREAD-2024F_01_25_02_18_09_2024.pdf</citation>, in accordance with Section 91 (2) of the Constitution, which means every seat in Parliament becomes vacant except for those of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker <citation>https://parliament.gov.bw/documents/PARLY-SPREAD-2024F_01_25_02_18_09_2024.pdf</citation>.
The UDC's Augustine Nyatanga won the Mahalapye East Constituency by-election <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82890</citation>.

Yandani Boko, the MP for Mahalapye East, resigned from Parliament citing emotional strain, marking the end of his political career <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/78284</citation>, <citation>https://parrotsug.com/mp-resigns-from-parliament-citing-emotional-strain/</citation>.

The Serowe West by-election was held on July 8, 2023, due to the expulsion of Tshekedi Khama (BPF) for missing the required number of parliamentary meetings <citation>https://detailedpedia.com/wiki-2023_Serowe_West_by-election</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/73289</citation>.

In the 2019-2024 parliament, four women were selected as specially elected MPs, but only three are women in the current parliament, bringing women's representation to six out of 67 <citation>https://theconversation.com/women-in-botswana-make-up-54-of-voters-but-less-than-10-of-parliament-political-parties-can-change-that-244527</citation>, <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20241220/281814289466634</citation>.

Floor crossing can act as a safety net for both individual MPs and political parties to resolve political differences <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/the-voice-botswana/20200724/282067689255527</citation>.

Signs of the BDP losing power became evident in 2019 when the opposition won approximately 80% of local government by-elections <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/a-bad-year-at-the-office-for-botswana-s-oldest-ruling-party-4870302</citation>.

### Composition of parliament

The Botswana Parliament is unicameral, consisting of the National Assembly <citation>https://www.indexmundi.com/botswana/legislative_branch.html</citation>. The National Assembly has 63 seats, with 57 members directly elected from single-seat constituencies, utilizing the First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) system <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, <citation>https://www.indexmundi.com/botswana/legislative_branch.html</citation>. Additionally, 4 members are nominated by the President and indirectly elected by the National Assembly <citation>https://www.indexmundi.com/botswana/legislative_branch.html</citation>. The President and the Attorney General serve as ex-officio members <citation>https://www.indexmundi.com/botswana/legislative_branch.html</citation>. The 12th Parliament, which was in session from 2019 to 2024, was dissolved on September 5, 2024, by the President, in accordance with Section 91 (2) of the Constitution <citation>https://parliament.gov.bw/documents/PARLY-SPREAD-2024F_01_25_02_18_09_2024.pdf</citation>.

In the 2019-2024 parliament, four women were selected as specially elected MPs; however, only three women are in the current parliament, bringing women's representation to six out of 67 <citation>https://theconversation.com/women-in-botswana-make-up-54-of-voters-but-less-than-10-of-parliament-political-parties-can-change-that-244527</citation>, <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20241220/281814289466634</citation>.

A new constitutional amendment mandates that Members of Parliament (MPs) resign if they switch parties mid-term, aiming to stabilize governance and respect voter mandates <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/floor-crossing-ban-reshapes-political-accountability</citation>, <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/floor-crossing-ban-reshapes-political-accountability/</citation>.

### Seat redistribution

The redistribution of parliamentary seats in Botswana is a critical process for ensuring fair and effective representation, mandated by Section 64.1 of the Constitution of Botswana <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/delimination-commission-hands-over-report-to-president-masisi/</citation>. This task is carried out by the Delimitation Commission, which is appointed by the Judicial Service Commission following the receipt of the National Population Census Report <citation>https://enews.mmegi.bw/article/281535114590127</citation>.

The Delimitation Commission, established on May 13, 2022, and sworn in on May 27, 2022 <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/delimination-commission-hands-over-report-to-president-masisi/</citation>, undertakes extensive consultations to gather input from various stakeholders. In 2022, the commission visited 104 places and held 106 consultation meetings, engaging with communities at kgotlas and community halls <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/71386</citation>, <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/delimination-commission-hands-over-report-to-president-masisi/</citation>. These consultations are vital for understanding local dynamics and ensuring that the proposed redistributions reflect the needs and concerns of the population. The 2022 Delimitation Commission report is accessible to the public online <citation>https://www.facebook.com/iecbotswana/posts/the-public-is-informed-that-you-can-now-access-the-2022-delimitation-commission-/529954135990631/</citation>, <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/images/2022_Delimitation_Final_Report.pdf</citation>.

One notable outcome of the Delimitation Commission's work is the splitting of Mogoditshane constituency due to its growing population <citation>https://enews.mmegi.bw/article/281543705100000</citation>. This decision reflects the commission's mandate to ensure that each constituency represents a roughly equal number of people, promoting the principle of "one person, one vote." The chairperson of the Delimitation Commission was Judge Mokwadi Chris Gabanagae <citation>https://enews.mmegi.bw/article/281535114590127</citation>.

### MPs not standing for re-election

Several Members of Parliament (MPs) concluded their political careers after the recent parliamentary session, either due to losses in primary elections or by opting for retirement <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>. This exodus was particularly noticeable among MPs from the ruling Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), often spurred by losses in the Bulela Ditswe primary elections, which paved the way for new faces <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>.

Kgosi Tawana Moremi II, the Maun West legislator, also added to the list of retiring MPs <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>. Additionally, Eric Molale, the MP for Good Hope/Mabule, announced that he would not seek re-election, citing old age as the reason, after serving in public service for over 40 years <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/77452</citation>,<citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/molale-throws-in-the-towel-2/</citation>. ### Observation controversy

The 2024 Botswana general election was not without controversy, particularly concerning the observation of the electoral process. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) took the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) to court, which led to postponements of voter registration in November, as the UDC sought permission to deploy registration observers <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>. This legal challenge underscores the importance the UDC placed on ensuring transparency and preventing potential irregularities during voter registration.

Claims of poll rigging have also been a recurring concern. In 2019, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) made claims of poll rigging ahead of the general election, which Botswana’s election commission warned against <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-s-electoral-body-warns-opposition-about-rigging-claims/7826626.html</citation>. These allegations highlight the need for robust oversight and impartial monitoring to maintain public trust in the electoral system.

To ensure a fair and transparent election, the African Union Election Observation Mission (AUEOM) was deployed to Botswana for the 2019 general election following an invitation from the Government of Botswana and the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) <citation>https://www.eisa.org/pdf/bot2019au.pdf</citation>. The AUEOM's presence and engagement with various stakeholders, including the IEC, political parties, candidates, and civil society, played a crucial role in promoting confidence in the electoral process.

## Campaign

The 2024 Botswana general election saw the two major parties, the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) and the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC), present their visions for the country through distinct campaign platforms.

The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP)'s 2024 election manifesto was described as realistic and forward-thinking, focusing on job creation, strengthening financial systems, and upholding democracy <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81509, https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/africa/2024-09-02-botswanas-president-masisi-launches-bdp-manifesto-ahead-of-2024-elections, https://en.sputniknews.africa/20240902/botswanas-president-masisi-launches-ruling-bdp-partys-manifesto-ahead-of-2024-elections-1068110390.html</citation>. President Masisi stated it was an achievable plan, not just promises, directing efforts towards growth, opportunities, and progress <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81509</citation>. The BDP also aimed to diversify the tourism industry and promote citizen inclusion through innovative offerings and world-class facilities <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/a-look-at-bdp-udc-key-manifesto-issues/news</citation>.

On the other hand, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC)'s campaign promises focused on rebuilding the economy, creating employment, and ending corruption <citation>https://issafrica.org/iss-today/great-expectations-as-democracy-wins-in-botswana</citation>. The UDC's manifesto, titled "Inclusive Growth and Quality Lives," included plans to increase the average salary to P10,000 or more, create an equitable economy with at least 10% annual growth, and launch a National Community Service programme with a monthly allowance of P2,500 <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>. A key promise was the creation of 450,000 to 500,000 jobs, addressing the high unemployment rate <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20241122/281608130987055</citation>. The UDC also aimed to position Botswana as a regional AI hub and implement reforms in education, housing, and healthcare <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/umbrella-for-democratic-change-udc-manifesto-highlights/</citation>.
## Election date and timeline

The 2024 Botswana general election was held on October 30, 2024 <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation>, <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation>, <citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/botswana-general-election-set-for-october-30-20240903</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation>, <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>, <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-to-hold-elections-october-30-as-president-masisi-seeks-2nd-term-/7770173.html</citation>. President Mokgweetsi Masisi officially set the date following his nomination as the BDP's presidential candidate <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation>. In accordance with Section 90(3) of the Constitution, Parliament was dissolved on September 5, 2024, setting the stage for the elections <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation>, <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>, <citation>https://parliament.gov.bw/documents/PARLY-SPREAD-2024F_01_25_02_18_09_2024.pdf</citation>. The presidential nomination court sat on September 28, 2024, at the Gaborone High Court <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation>, and the parliamentary and local council candidates' names were submitted by October 4, 2024 <citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/botswana-general-election-set-for-october-30-20240903</citation>. Writs of Election were issued by the President and the Minister of Local Government and Rural Development on August 30 for the 2019 General Elections (presumably a similar process occurred in 2024) <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/51509</citation>. The Constitution mandates that general elections occur within 60 days following the dissolution of Parliament <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>, <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/mmegi/20240628/281642490363303</citation>. To vote, citizens must be 18 years and above and possess a valid National Identity Card and Voter Registration Card <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/elections.html</citation>.

The 2024 Botswana general election saw the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) losing power after nearly six decades <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>, <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>, <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>. President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded defeat to Duma Boko of the UDC <citation>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article/opposition-party-wins-overwhelming-majority-in-botswana-election/</citation>, <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>, marking a historic moment <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. The UDC secured 26 seats in Botswana's 61-seat legislature based on partial results <citation>https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/investing/2024/11/01/shock-election-outcome-ends-botswana-ruling-partys-58-year-rule/</citation>. The BDP's loss is attributed to an economic downturn caused by a collapse in the diamond market, leading to a 28% unemployment rate <citation>https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/investing/2024/11/01/shock-election-outcome-ends-botswana-ruling-partys-58-year-rule/</citation>. Duma Boko suggested this presents an opportunity for the government to acquire a substantial stake in De Beers <citation>https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/investing/2024/11/01/shock-election-outcome-ends-botswana-ruling-partys-58-year-rule/</citation>. The 2024 election results open discussions about representation and electoral reform in Botswana, which uses the First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) system <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC)'s campaign promises focused on rebuilding the economy, creating employment, and ending corruption <citation>https://issafrica.org/iss-today/great-expectations-as-democracy-wins-in-botswana</citation>. President Duma Boko attributed the UDC's victory to the will of the people, faith in God, and divine intervention <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/83287</citation>, promising inclusive governance <citation>https://ireportsouthafrica.co.za/2024/11/02/duma-boko-wins-botswanas-presidential-election-sparks-wave-of-congratulatory-messages-from-across-africa/</citation>. Masisi pledged to support the new administration <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/the-voice-botswana/20241101/281492166821388</citation>. Mokgweetsi Masisi handed over his office to Duma Boko on November 4, 2024 <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>.
## Preface

The 2024 Botswana general election marked a watershed moment in the nation's political history. Since gaining independence in 1966, Botswana had been governed by the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. However, the 2024 election saw the BDP lose power after nearly six decades of dominance, signaling a significant shift in the country's political landscape <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>.

The main contenders in the election were the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC), led by Duma Boko, and the incumbent Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), led by President Mokgweetsi Masisi <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>. Other parties that participated in the election included the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) and the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>.

This report will delve into the key aspects of the 2024 Botswana election, including the factors that led to the BDP's defeat, the campaign promises of the UDC, and the implications of the power transition for Botswana's future. It will also examine the election results, the composition of the new cabinet, and the challenges and opportunities facing the new administration. The peaceful transfer of power in Botswana serves as an example of a successful democratic transition, and this report aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of this historic event <citation>https://eng.fatshimetrie.org/2024/11/04/botswanas-historic-political-transition-in-2024/</citation>.
## Results

The 2024 Botswana general election marked a historic shift in the country's political landscape, ending nearly six decades of dominance by the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) since independence in 1966 <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>, <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>. President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded defeat to Duma Boko of the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) <citation>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-opposition-party-wins-overwhelming-majority-in-botswana-election/</citation>. Voter turnout in the 2024 parliamentary elections was 81% <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured a majority in the National Assembly, winning 36 out of the 61 seats <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>. Other parties' results were as follows: the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) secured 15 seats, becoming the second-largest party in the National Assembly <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82945</citation>; the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) obtained 5 seats <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82945</citation>; and the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) won only 4 parliamentary seats <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82945</citation>. An independent candidate, Dr. Edwin Dikoloti, won one seat <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>.

The 2024 election results have initiated discussions about representation and potential electoral reforms in Botswana <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, which currently uses the First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) majority system for National Assembly and Local Government elections <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) received 31% of the popular vote but won only 4 seats, highlighting the imbalances of the FPTP system <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/botswana-elections-2024-just-but-unfair/</citation>. The Gallagher Index could be used to measure the proportionality of parliamentary seats won in the 2024 election.
## Voter registration

In Botswana, any citizen aged 18 years and above is eligible to register to vote in national and local government elections <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php?title=Botswana_-_Obtain_a_Voters_card</citation>. To register, eligible citizens must possess a valid National Identity Card (Omang) <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation> and Voter Registration Card <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/elections.html</citation>. The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) conducts voter registration, often announcing general registration periods <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>. During these periods, citizens can visit a Registration Officer with their Omang, who will then complete a registration form <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>.

For the 2024 general elections, voter registration commenced on January 5 and concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-records-a-decline-in-registered-voters/news</citation>, <citation>https://newsinvasion24.com/botswana-wraps-up-voter-registration-for-2024-elections/</citation>. By the end of the registration period, a total of 1,038,275 voters had registered, marking an increase of 112,800 from the 2019 elections <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/over-one-million-voters-for-2024-elections/</citation>. The IEC aimed for 80% voter registration, targeting 1.3 million voters <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>, <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-exceeds-historic-1-million-mark-in-voter-registration/</citation>.

A voter who wishes to transfer their registration to a different polling station must bring their current Voter's Registration Card to a Registration Officer in the constituency where the new polling station is located <citation>https://cms2.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration-transfer</citation>. Voter registration cards are valid indefinitely, except when a voter transfers registration to a new electoral area <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php/Botswana_-_Register_as_Voter</citation>.
### Background of opposition parties before the election

Botswana has been a multi-party state since independence in 1966, but the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) has been the dominant force in the country's politics, holding power since 1969 <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>. However, the opposition parties have been challenging the BDP's dominance, especially in recent years <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>. Historically, the opposition has been fragmented and weak, but has experienced an upswell in confidence since its victory in the 2022 by-elections <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>. If the opposition parties are able to overcome factionalism and slightly increase their popular support, 2024 may mark the end of a 57-year legacy of the BDP’s rule in Botswana <citation>https://blog.bti-project.org/2024/08/29/a-bumpy-road-ahead-botswana-faces-economic-and-political-struggles-ahead-of-its-2024-general-elections/</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC), a coalition formed in the lead-up to the 2019 elections and led by Duma Boko, represented the strongest challenge to the BDP <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>. In the 2019 election, the UDC more than doubled its share of seats, from 15 to 36 <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/elections/elections/</citation>. Other key opposition parties included the Botswana Congress Party (BCP), led by Mr. Dumelang Saleshando <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/elections/elections/</citation>, the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF), which was formed just before the 2019 election by former President Ian Khama <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>, and the Alliance for Progressives (AP).

Botswana operates under a First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) electoral system, which has been criticized for disadvantaging smaller parties <citation>https://freedomhouse.org/country/botswana/freedom-world/2025</citation>. This system can magnify majorities in certain constituencies but fails to represent actual voter support across the nation <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/botswana-elections-2024-just-but-unfair/</citation>.
### Composition of parliament

The Botswana Parliament is unicameral, consisting of the National Assembly <citation>https://www.indexmundi.com/botswana/legislative_branch.html</citation>. The National Assembly has 63 seats, with 57 members directly elected from single-seat constituencies, utilizing the First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) system <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, <citation>https://www.indexmundi.com/botswana/legislative_branch.html</citation>. Additionally, 4 members are nominated by the President and indirectly elected by the National Assembly <citation>https://www.indexmundi.com/botswana/legislative_branch.html</citation>. The President and the Attorney General serve as ex-officio members <citation>https://www.indexmundi.com/botswana/legislative_branch.html</citation>. The 12th Parliament, which was in session from 2019 to 2024, was dissolved on September 5, 2024, by the President, in accordance with Section 91 (2) of the Constitution <citation>https://parliament.gov.bw/documents/PARLY-SPREAD-2024F_01_25_02_18_09_2024.pdf</citation>.

In the 2019-2024 parliament, four women were selected as specially elected MPs; however, only three women are in the current parliament, bringing women's representation to six out of 67 <citation>https://theconversation.com/women-in-botswana-make-up-54-of-voters-but-less-than-10-of-parliament-political-parties-can-change-that-244527</citation>, <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20241220/281814289466634</citation>.

A new constitutional amendment mandates that Members of Parliament (MPs) resign if they switch parties mid-term, aiming to stabilize governance and respect voter mandates <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/floor-crossing-ban-reshapes-political-accountability</citation>, <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/floor-crossing-ban-reshapes-political-accountability/</citation>.
### Previous election

The 2019 Botswana general election saw the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) secure victory, winning 29 national assembly seats and representing 51 percent of the vote <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/10/25/botswanas-ruling-party-bdp-wins-general-election-chief-justice/</citation>. The election marked the first time Mokgweetsi Masisi led the BDP as president, having succeeded Ian Khama in 2018 <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20191023/</citation>.

The BDP's popular vote surged from 46.7% to 66.66% in the 2019 election <citation>https://www.politicalanalysis.co.za/botswanas-ruling-party-wins-37-of-the-57-parliamentary-seats/</citation>, allowing them to retain a majority in the 65-member National Assembly with 38 of the 57 seats at stake <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20191023/</citation>.

The 2019 election was significantly influenced by former President Ian Khama <citation>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03057070.2020.1778901</citation>. In the run-up to the election, a power struggle erupted within the ruling BDP <citation>https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/botswana/politics-2019.htm</citation>, and Khama, who left the ruling party, backed the opposition <citation>https://mg.co.za/article/2019-10-17-khamas-hand-still-rocks-botswana/</citation>.

The 2019 Botswana elections were marred by allegations of irregularity <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/udc-working-on-strategies-to-prevent-election-rigging/news</citation>. Forensics for Justice claimed to have evidence that the election was fraudulently rigged to favor the BDP, allegedly assisted by intelligence services <citation>https://www.biznews.com/global-citizen/2019/12/05/botswana-election-rigged-forensics-justice</citation>. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) also made claims of poll rigging ahead of the election <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-s-electoral-body-warns-opposition-about-rigging-claims/7826626.html</citation>. Following the elections, the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) faced numerous legal challenges in the form of election petitions due to the non-acceptance of election results <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/images/Stakeholders+REPORT_Feb+26+2021.pdf</citation>. The UDC challenged the election results in court for 16 parliamentary constituencies won by the BDP <citation>https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/botswana-opposition-challenges-election-result-in-court-2019-11-26</citation>.

The African Union Election Observation Mission (AUEOM) was deployed to Botswana for the 2019 general election <citation>https://www.eisa.org/pdf/bot2019au.pdf</citation> and commended the IEC for providing voter information on Election Day, such as displaying names and symbols of contesting parties and independent candidates at polling stations <citation>https://www.eisa.org/pdf/bot2019au.pdf</citation>.
### Seat redistribution

The redistribution of parliamentary seats in Botswana is a critical process for ensuring fair and effective representation, mandated by Section 64.1 of the Constitution of Botswana <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/delimination-commission-hands-over-report-to-president-masisi/</citation>. This task is carried out by the Delimitation Commission, which is appointed by the Judicial Service Commission following the receipt of the National Population Census Report <citation>https://enews.mmegi.bw/article/281535114590127</citation>.

The Delimitation Commission, established on May 13, 2022, and sworn in on May 27, 2022 <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/delimination-commission-hands-over-report-to-president-masisi/</citation>, undertakes extensive consultations to gather input from various stakeholders. In 2022, the commission visited 104 places and held 106 consultation meetings, engaging with communities at kgotlas and community halls <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/71386</citation>, <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/delimination-commission-hands-over-report-to-president-masisi/</citation>. These consultations are vital for understanding local dynamics and ensuring that the proposed redistributions reflect the needs and concerns of the population. The 2022 Delimitation Commission report is accessible to the public online <citation>https://www.facebook.com/iecbotswana/posts/the-public-is-informed-that-you-can-now-access-the-2022-delimitation-commission-/529954135990631/</citation>, <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/images/2022_Delimitation_Final_Report.pdf</citation>.

One notable outcome of the Delimitation Commission's work is the splitting of Mogoditshane constituency due to its growing population <citation>https://enews.mmegi.bw/article/281543705100000</citation>. This decision reflects the commission's mandate to ensure that each constituency represents a roughly equal number of people, promoting the principle of "one person, one vote." The chairperson of the Delimitation Commission was Judge Mokwadi Chris Gabanagae <citation>https://enews.mmegi.bw/article/281535114590127</citation>.
### MPs not standing for re-election

Several Members of Parliament (MPs) concluded their political careers after the recent parliamentary session, either due to losses in primary elections or by opting for retirement <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>. This exodus was particularly noticeable among MPs from the ruling Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), often spurred by losses in the Bulela Ditswe primary elections, which paved the way for new faces <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>.

Notable examples include Edwin Batshu, the former Police Commissioner, who completed two terms as the MP for Nkange <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>. Kgosi Tawana Moremi II, the Maun West legislator, also added to the list of retiring MPs <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>. Additionally, Eric Molale, the MP for Good Hope/Mabule, announced that he would not seek re-election, citing old age as the reason, after serving in public service for over 40 years <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/77452</citation>,<citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/molale-throws-in-the-towel-2/</citation>. Mpho Balopi, the incumbent MP for Gaborone North, had also announced his decision not to participate in the 2024 general elections <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/animosity-rises-as-bdp-primaries-near/</citation>, which led to him vacating his parliamentary seat and the office of BDP Secretary General <citation>https://thevoicebw.com/set-to-cruise/</citation>. Pono Moatlhodi, the MP for Tonota, also announced his intention to retire from active politics at the end of his term in 2024 <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/69649</citation>. Dr. Thapelo Matsheka, the former MP for Lobatse, declared he would not vie for any position at the Botswana Democratic Party's upcoming congress <citation>https://thevoicebw.com/matsheka-bows-out-of-bdp-succession-race/</citation>.
### Presidential nominees

The High Court of Botswana confirmed four presidential candidates for the 2024 general election: Mokgweetsi Masisi, the candidate for the ruling Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-leader-3-from-opposition-confirmed-as-presidential-candidates-/7804891.html</citation>; Duma Boko, leader of the opposition coalition Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-leader-3-from-opposition-confirmed-as-presidential-candidates-/7804891.html</citation>; Dumelang Saleshando of the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-leader-3-from-opposition-confirmed-as-presidential-candidates-/7804891.html</citation>; and Mephato Reatile from the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-leader-3-from-opposition-confirmed-as-presidential-candidates-/7804891.html</citation>.

The presidential nomination process was conducted in accordance with the constitution and under the supervision of the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81985</citation>. The presidential nomination court convened on September 28, 2024, at the Gaborone High Court <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation>. The Chief Justice of Botswana serves as the returning officer for presidential elections, as stipulated by Sections 32 and 38 of the Constitution and Section 2 of the Presidential Elections Act <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/77718</citation>.

However, Biggie Butale, leader of the Botswana Republican Party (BRP), failed to meet the legal requirements for nomination and was therefore not confirmed as a presidential candidate <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2024/10/01/botswana-leader-3-from-opposition-confirmed-as-presidential-candidates/</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82038</citation>.
### Observation controversy

The 2024 Botswana general election was not without controversy, particularly concerning the observation of the electoral process. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) took the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) to court, which led to postponements of voter registration in November, as the UDC sought permission to deploy registration observers <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>. This legal challenge underscores the importance the UDC placed on ensuring transparency and preventing potential irregularities during voter registration.

Claims of poll rigging have also been a recurring concern. In 2019, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) made claims of poll rigging ahead of the general election, which Botswana’s election commission warned against <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-s-electoral-body-warns-opposition-about-rigging-claims/7826626.html</citation>. These allegations highlight the need for robust oversight and impartial monitoring to maintain public trust in the electoral system.

To ensure a fair and transparent election, the African Union Election Observation Mission (AUEOM) was deployed to Botswana for the 2019 general election following an invitation from the Government of Botswana and the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) <citation>https://www.eisa.org/pdf/bot2019au.pdf</citation>. The AUEOM's presence and engagement with various stakeholders, including the IEC, political parties, candidates, and civil society, played a crucial role in promoting confidence in the electoral process.
